anchor.surface_text: requirements of procedure are generally intended to subserve the ends of justice, and so, undue emphasis on mere technicalities in respect of matters which are number of vital or important significance in a criminal trial, may sometimes frustrate the ends of justice. Where the provisions prescribed by the law of procedure are intended to be mandatory, the legislature indicates its intention in that behalf clearly and companytravention of such mandatory provisions may introduce a serious infirmity in the proceedings themselves but where the provisions made by the law of procedure are number of vital importance, but are, nevertheless, intended to be observed, their breach may number necessarily vitiate the trial unless it is shown that the companytravention in question has caused prejudice to the accused. This position is made clear by sections 535 and 537 Cr. P. C.

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully read the charge and we are satisfied that on the whole, the charge has number only been fair, but has. been more in favour of the appellant than in favour of the prosecution.

holdings.text: The charge specifying periods of four to six days instead of precise dates and times does not contravene section 222(1) Cr.P.C. as it provided reasonable notice to the accused and no prejudice was caused.

anchor.surface_text: Even under s.222(1), 'on or about' date is usual; short periods ok if reasonable notice. If it is permissible to say in a charge that a particular offence was committed on or about a specified date...

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.222 requires particulars reasonably sufficient for notice; usual to use 'on or about'; short periods permissible absent prejudice; precision depends on prosecution information; ss.535/537 require prejudice for vitiation; applied to facts, no prejudice shown; Ali Hyder distinguished.

holdings.text: A High Court may summarily dismiss a criminal appeal under s.421 Cr.P.C. without reasons if, after perusing the petition and copy, it finds no arguable or substantial question warranting interference.

anchor.surface_text: Section 421(1) of the Code provides that on receiving the petition and copy under s.419 or s.420, the appellate court shall peruse the same, and, if it considers that there is no sufficient ground for interfering, it may dismiss the appeal summarily.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of s.421 allows dismissal post-perusal if no substance; no obligation to call records or give reasons; Mushtak Hussein and Shreekantiah disapproved summary dismissal only where arguable points exist, but here none; High Court satisfied no merit.

holdings.text: Sessions Judge did not misdirect jury by leaving question of charge validity to them, as it favoured prosecution given prior High Court upholding of charge.

anchor.surface_text: We should have stated earlier that after the committal order was passed by the presidency Magistrate, the appellant moved the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction and urged that the charge framed against him was defective and invalid and should be quashed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Validity of charge is question of law previously upheld by High Court in revision, binding on Sessions Judge; leaving open to jury allowed acquittal possibility despite prior ruling, thus no prejudice to accused.

holdings.text: Sessions Judge's charge to jury on corroboration of prosecutrix was fair and adequate, elaborately explaining need for corroboration as prudence, warning uncorroborated testimony unsafe, and highlighting contradictions.

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully read the charge and we are satisfied that on the whole, the charge has not only been fair, but has been more in favour of the appellant than in favour of the prosecution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judge explained prosecutrix as key witness with little corroboration; warned against conviction on uncorroborated testimony unless fully convinced of truthfulness; noted material contradictions; overall charge favoured defence.

holdings.text: Sessions Judge did not materially misdirect on onus of proof for prosecutrix's age, having earlier explained prosecution must prove below 16.

anchor.surface_text: In the first part of his charge, the learned judge explained to the jury the essential requirements which had to be proved by the prosecution in support of its charge under s.376, and there the learned judge had made it clear to the jury that the prosecution had to show that the girl was below 16.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Onus already stated in initial explanation of s.376 elements; summarising conflicting age evidence without repeating onus not material misdirection absent prejudice.

holdings.text: Previous statements under s.145 Evidence Act are for contradiction only, not substantive evidence; Sessions Judge correctly directed jury accordingly.

anchor.surface_text: Now, it is clear that when a previous statement is put to a witness in cross-examination under s.145 of the Indian Evidence Act, its primary purpose is to contradict the witness by reference to the evidence he gives at the trial, and so, it cannot be said that the learned judge was wrong in law...

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.145 purpose is contradiction, impeaching credibility; not independent proof; direction accurately states law.

holdings.text: Sessions Judge not required to treat unanimous jury verdict as perverse despite prosecutrix's uncorroborated testimony and charge highlighting weaknesses.

anchor.surface_text: In his charge, the learned judge no doubt indicated that the evidence of the girl was not satisfactory, that it was not corroborated and that there were other circumstances which showed that the prosecution case might be improbable, but having done his duty...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judge highlighted flaws but left facts to jury; post-deliberation unanimous guilty verdict not perverse; judge accepts unless perverse.

holdings.text: Procedural irregularities, including in charges under Cr.P.C., do not vitiate trial unless accused shows prejudice caused thereby (per ss.535, 537 Cr.P.C.).

anchor.surface_text: requirements of procedure are generally intended to subserve the ends of justice... their breach may not necessarily vitiate the trial unless it is shown that the contravention in question has caused prejudice to the accused. This position is made clear by sections 535 and 537 Cr. P. C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural rules subserve justice ends; mandatory vs directory distinction; prejudice test central to validity; illustrated by murder circumstantial cases.
